awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  Grid-scale electricity storage from waste heat
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) project is to unleash the potential of water as a thermal energy storage medium for building air conditioning. Today’s commercial ice storage systems, based on Ice-on-Coil (IOC) technology, fails to capture this potential because efficiently moving thermal energy into and out of water as it freezes and melts is challenging. The proposed Icephobic Heat Exchange (IHEX) technology eliminates the adhesion of freezing water to cold surfaces, preventing ice buildup on the coil and realizing the power of water for low-cost, high efficiency, resilient building cooling. IHEX based thermal storage removes the primary barriers to product adoption: high cost and spatial constraint limitations. It helps building owners lower their cooling costs, strengthen their cooling resiliency, and reduce their carbon emissions through affordable and spatially adaptable solutions. From a broader perspective, storing energy is imperative to a sustainable electric grid. Globally, an estimated potential for up to 2.8% of worldwide GHG emissions can be offset through full scale deployment of IHEX technology in building cooling. Beyond reliable access to power from intermittent renewable sources, cost-effective thermal storage can increase cooling resiliency by meeting cooling demand when the electric grid is down.

This SBIR Phase II project proposes to catalyze development of IHEX technology by demonstrating high reliability for IHEX materials and establish high energy density, efficiency, and cooling resiliency for commercial-scale IHEX systems. IOC systems use miles of tubing to generate the necessary amount of surface area for heat transfer, which is costly and energy intensive, and their modular systems require significant space. This project will demonstrate that IHEX technology meets all the existing strengths of IOC technology, such as durability, while addressing potential economic concerns.  First, materials testing will be completed after a year’s worth of freeze/melt cycling on a prototype-scale system to indicate long IHEX system life. Second, the ability to use customizable storage tanks with high energy density will be demonstrated. Customizable, space-filling tanks will help IHEX technology eliminate the physical space constraints that have thwarted so many commercial projects. Third, a commercial-scale IHEX system will be used to derive a 20% energy efficiency improvement compared to IOC solutions and a low, $28/ton-hr cost. And finally, by working with our product end-users and industry, a 67% reduction in total cost of ownership compared to conventional cooling systems will be shown.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
The purpose of this project was to scale up a novel thermal energy storage technology called icephobic heat exchange (IHEX) to a power output relevant for commercial applications. Unfortunately, through the course of development and testing, it was determined that IHEX technology did not scale well: the plate heat exchange performance scaled poorly, and the operational reliability was challenging, leading to frequent system failures. Once these limitations were well quantified and understood, our team developed a next-generation version of the technology, leveraging all the know-how and capabilities previously developed. We leveraged direct contact heat exchange (DCHX), where a working fluid is cooled to below 0 °C than put into contact with water. DCHX technology provided similar, if not improved benefits to IHEX technology:

  1. fully discharge the stored energy in less than 4 hours
  2. a ~5% higher ice-making efficiency than traditional ice-on-coil systems
  3. match the building’s available shape by using tanks of varying sizes and shapes
  4. elimination of complex or hard to manufacture features, reducing cost and complexity

With this approach, we met the project’s scaling objectives.

Objective 1: Material reliability

We investigated how the thermal energy storage materials performed over 300 cycles and multiple years of operation: no observed reduction in system performance was attributable to materials degradation. As DCHX and IHEX use the same set of materials, this result is also relevant to the DCHX system.

Objective 2: Energy density (ice fraction) and tank customizability

We demonstrated that 40% of the stored water could be stored as ice in the tank, which was the target, with room for improvement. We also showed that two tanks of different shapes and sizes can be used, to a limited extent: one of the tanks was not at a commercially relevant scale. We will validate the customizability with a larger tank in the future.

Objective 3: Scaled-up system operation at high efficiency and low marginal storage cost

A 35 kWt (10 ton) ice-making thermal energy storage system with 315 kWht (90 ton-hours) of storage was designed, constructed, and tested at the company’s facility. Both the targeted ice-making efficiency and marginal storage cost were not met with DCHX: the former was limited to an ~5% gain compared to the incumbent technology, whereas the latter was proven to be ~$45/ton-hour. However, both values are notable improvements and lead to an economically attractive thermal energy storage system, which is ultimately the goal.

Objective 4: Clear pathway to reduced total cost of ownership (TCO) of the cooling system 

We showed that DCHX leads to a system with TCO reduction of 67% or greater in one design configuration and with a payback of less than 4 years in another configuration, even being the lowest capital cost option in some cases.

 


Last Modified: 03/31/2024
Modified by: Levon Atoyan
